review.title: New Ideas for Brain Modelling 2
review.abstract: This paper describes a relatively simple way of allowing a brain model to self-organise its concept patterns through nested structures. Time is a key element and a simulator would be able to show how patterns may form and then fire in sequence, as part of a search or thought process. It uses a very simple equation to show how the inhibitors in particular, can switch off certain areas, to allow other areas to become the prominent ones and thereby define the current brain state. This allows for a small amount of control over what appears to be a chaotic structure inside of the brain. It is attractive because it is still mostly mechanical and therefore can be added as an automatic process, or the modelling of that. The paper also describes how the nested pattern structure can be used as a basic counting mechanism. This extended version integrates further with the existing cognitive model and provides new conclusions.

sections.text: Conceptual Patterns through Nested Structures. Time is a key element and a simulator could show how patterns can form and then fire one after the other as part of a search or thought process. It uses a very simple equation to show how, in particular, the inhibitors can turn off certain areas so that other areas can become the most prominent, thus defining the current state of the brain. This allows for a low degree of control over an apparently chaotic structure within the brain. It is attractive because it is still largely mechanical and can therefore be added as an automatic process or modeling it. The paper also describes how the nested pattern structure can be used as a basic counting mechanism. This enhanced version1 further integrates with the existing cognitive model and delivers new conclusions. Keywords: neural modeling, self-organization, connectivity strengths, mathematical process.

sections.heading: 4.2 Test Results
sections.text: The test results are fairly simple and show the desired pattern of 7.5 relative counts or signal strengths. Only the traditional increment / decrement algorithm is represented in Table 1. In total, there are 25 neurons and 5 in each nested pattern. The inhibitory signal is set to half of an excitatory pattern, but if a pattern contains only 5 neurons, there are 20 other neurons that could send inhibitory signals. Each firing cycle activates a new nested pattern until all patterns are active. Afterwards, each firing cycle would update signals from all patterns. The inhibitory signal is sent from the inner pattern only to its outer ones, so that the innermost does not receive inhibitory signals. When all patterns are active, the inhibitory signal builds up to overwhelm the excitatory signal. This, of course, depends on the preset relative strengths and numbers of excitation and inhibitory signals.

sections.text: It turns out that the nested ensembles fit into the current cognitive model described in [5] [6] [7] and most recently in [4]. All the elements mentioned in previous work are still relevant and can therefore be further refined. Although it may not be 100% biologically correct, it is fairly detailed and still consistent in terms of the main ideas.

sections.heading: 5.3 One-way System?
sections.text: One might think that most processes are one-way systems that are cyclical in nature. Although newer brain models have fibrous or tree-like branching properties in the broadest granularity, cyclic or circular completions are very easy to understand, but assume that the whole process is "like one," assuming that the signals flowing must be very similar, while they are consistent with the known neuron functionality, there may be other problems. On the one hand, there are certain regions in the brain, and so signals would have to cross boundaries and shift the hierarchy downwards in the neocortex (or the simulated neural network model) to complete the cycle upwards, which in turn alters functionality. Thus, another suggestion can be made to complete a signal. An alternative way to complete a circuit is to have (at least) two halves that meet or connect, which is possible for a number of reasons, again an attractive one.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: The purpose of this paper is to show how nested or more specific patterns can become the main focus in a generally aroused area, and they could even be used as part of more complex mathematical processes. Instead of detailing how they arise or intertwine, etc., the paper describes how they could be useful. Simulation would be easier if the interaction between the patterns were only taken into account by using a general equation for their relative strengths. The mechanical process can also work with a minimum of complexity, allowing these patterns to form and burn in sequence, and it would also realize a certain degree of natural order that would be better than the very random and chaotic structures that seem to be present. As described in Section 2, the mechanism is still compatible with previous work, and the second purpose of this paper is to integrate the new knowledge into the overall cognitive model. It appears that the nested ensembles are almost seamlessly incorporated into the existing ensembles and are helpful in the study of other ideas.
